user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl(char *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    const void *                  addrbuffer;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in.sin_addr;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            addrbuffer = &Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_addr;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    if (inet_ntop(Accessor->sa.sa_family, addrbuffer, buffer, buflen) == NULL)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrToString_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I examined the function and the related definitions for constructs that would constitute compiler language extensions (for example: __attribute__/*GNU attributes*/, __extension__, nested functions, typeof, statement expressions, anonymous structs/unions not standardized by C, asm statements, or other compiler-specific keywords). None are present. Specific notes:

- The cast: Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData; is standard C pointer casting, not a compiler extension (though it may raise aliasing or alignment concerns, those are semantic/memory-safety issues, not language-extension use).
- The union and struct usage (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t containing char array and sockaddr variants) are standard C unions/structs; the conditional inclusion of sockaddr_in6 via #ifdef is standard preprocessor use.
- The #ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 and related macro definitions are standard preprocessor features; an empty macro definition ("#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 ") is still a standard macro definition and not a compiler extension.
- Use of inet_ntop and AF_INET/AF_INET6 are library/OS API items (POSIX/Networking), not compiler language extensions.
- Return statements, switch/case, and other control-flow constructs are standard C.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that use language extensions as defined by compiler documentation, so nothing needs to be reported for investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
